questions.text: A 78-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hearing loss in both ears over the past year. He has difficulties understanding conversations in crowded places and when more than one person talks at the same time. He has no dizziness, ear discharge, ringing noise, or ear pain. He has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows pearly gray, translucent tympanic membranes with a normal light reflex. A vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Once the patient no longer hears a tone, the fork is held over the ipsilateral ear and the patient reports hearing the tone again. The same test is repeated on the right side with similar results. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction is a buildup of tightly packed cerumen in the outer ear. It often manifests with unilateral conductive hearing loss and earache, and is easily diagnosed by direct visualization by otoscopic examination. This patient has bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and clear tympanic membranes on examination.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the external auditory canal

The auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.

B) INCORRECT:

Ototoxicity typically manifests with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as seen in this patient. However, the patient does not report being exposed to any classic ototoxic drugs such as aminoglycosides, furosemide, cisplatin, or aspirin. Furthermore, ototoxicity often manifests with additional symptoms like tinnitus, nystagmus, and dizziness, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis predominantly affects women aged 20–40 years and leads to conductive hearing loss, usually ultimately bilateral, which presents with a negative Rinne test as opposed to the sensorineural hearing loss seen in this patient. Additionally, patients also develop tinnitus and usually hear better in noisy rather than quiet surroundings.

D) INCORRECT:

Cholesteatoma manifests with conductive hearing loss, which would lead to a negative Rinne test, and if unilateral, lateralization to the affected ear on Weber test. In addition, it typically leads to painless otorrhea and a brownish, irregular mass on otoscopy, none of which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a vestibulocochlear nerve lesion presents with sensorineural hearing loss, it also leads to vestibular symptoms such as vertigo or horizontal nystagmus, none of which are present in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Presbycusis is a form of sensorineural hearing loss that affects more than half of adults by the age of 75 years, most adults over 80 years of age, and nearly all adults ≥ 90 years of age. It is a multifactorial process caused by gradual degeneration of the organ of Corti over the course of years, often first identified by difficulty hearing in crowded spaces. Although there is no definitive treatment, hearing aids and cochlear implants can provide symptomatic relief and improve hearing function in affected individuals.

G) INCORRECT:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that often lead to sensorineural hearing loss, and could become bilateral in cases of neurofibromatosis type 2. However, hearing loss would typically initially be asymmetric and also often present with tinnitus and vestibular nerve involvement, resulting in dizziness, unsteady gait, and disequilibrium. These findings are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).
questions.hint: This older patient presents with progressive bilateral hearing loss and difficulty hearing in noisy, crowded environments. These features together with bilateral positive Rinne test and no lateralization on Weber test are suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-year history of progressive hearing loss. His hearing is worse in crowded rooms, and he has noticed that he has more difficulty understanding women than men. He has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. A Rinne test shows air conduction is greater than bone conduction bilaterally. This condition is most likely associated with damage closest to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abnormalities of the external acoustic meatus (e.g., cerumen impaction) cause conductive hearing loss because sound is not able to travel through the ear canal. However, as in all conductive hearing abnormalities, the Rinne test would be abnormal (i.e., bone conduction greater than air conduction).

B) INCORRECT:

Damage or decreased mobility of the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss because it means sound is unable to travel from the external ear to the middle ear ossicles. Causes of tympanic membrane abnormalities include otitis media and acoustic trauma that involves perforation of the tympanic membrane. However, as in all conductive hearing abnormalities, the Rinne test would be abnormal (i.e., bone conduction greater than air conduction).

C) CORRECT:

Sound waves cause vibrations that resonate with the basilar membrane of the cochlea, which converts this input into nerve signals that encode the auditory information. The sound wave's point of optimal resonance within the cochlea depends on the frequency of the sound wave (tonotopy). The base of the cochlea, including the basal turn, responds to higher frequencies. Progressive degeneration of the organ of Corti near this region causes presbycusis.

Since hearing loss in presbycusis is typically bilateral and symmetrical, the Weber test does not usually lateralize to a particular ear.

D) INCORRECT:

The helicotrema is located near the apex of the cochlea. Lower frequency sound waves vibrate the basilar membrane of the helicotrema, which converts this input into nerve signals that encode the auditory information. This patient with presbycusis has no difficulty hearing low-frequency sounds (e.g., men's voices), which indicates that the helicotrema is not damaged.

E) INCORRECT:

When sound waves compress the oval window through the footplate of the stapes, the communicating perilymph pushes the round window membrane outwards, which allows the sound wave to travel through the cochlea and vibrate the basilar membrane. Acute changes in perilymphatic pressure (e.g., from loud noises or during diving, violent nose-blowing, or lifting heavy weights) can rupture the round window and manifest as sensorineural hearing loss (air conduction greater than bone conduction on Rinne test). However, the onset would be acute, asymmetrical, independent of the sound frequency, and typically associated with tinnitus and vertigo.

F) INCORRECT:

Damage to the base of the stapes causes conductive hearing loss because it prevents sound from being conducted to the oval window. Otosclerosis, the most common cause of conductive hearing loss in older adults, causes impaired mobility of the stapes. However, as in all conductive hearing abnormalities, the Rinne test would be abnormal (i.e., bone conduction greater than air conduction).
questions.hint: Age-related, progressive, bilateral hearing loss at higher frequencies (e.g., women's voices) that worsens in noisy environments is the key feature of presbycusis, the most common type of hearing loss in older adults. Since sound conduction is unaffected, the Rinne test is normal bilaterally (air conduction is greater than bone conduction).

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of hearing loss. He reports difficulty hearing sounds like the beeping of the microwave or birds chirping, but can easily hear the pipe organ at church. He works as an aircraft marshaller. A Rinne test shows air conduction greater than bone conduction bilaterally. A Weber test does not lateralize. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Damage to the organ of Corti

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Perforation of the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss and thus results in an abnormal Rinne test. Tympanic membrane perforation can be caused by foreign body trauma, temporal bone fractures, otitis media, barotrauma, or blast injury. While this patient's occupation puts him at increased risk of damage to the ear, there is nothing in this patient's history to suggest tympanic membrane perforation and the Rinne test was normal, indicating that he does not have conductive hearing loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Immobility of the stapes is the cause of otosclerosis, which can result in conductive hearing loss. The stapes lies against the oval window and transmits sounds from the tympanic membrane. In otosclerosis, the ossicles are rendered immobile by extensive bony remodeling. Patients usually present with bilateral conductive hearing loss and have an abnormal Rinne test. Otosclerosis would not be responsible for the bilateral sensorineural hearing loss seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

External compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve can be caused by tumors such as acoustic neuromas, which are usually unilateral, although they may be bilateral in neurofibromatosis type 2. Compression of this nerve would also result in sensorineural hearing loss. However, acoustic neuromas are usually accompanied by dizziness and ataxia, and they are unlikely to cause isolated symmetrical high-frequency hearing loss. Given this patient's history of chronic exposure to loud noises, a different etiology of his hearing loss is much more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the oval window is a cause of hearing loss associated with barotrauma. Sudden decreases in pressure between the inner and outer ear cause dissolved gasses to be released from the perilymphatic fluid in the inner ear and results in rupture of the oval window. Patients with barotrauma will have a recent history of diving or flying, which this patient does not. In addition, the sensorineural hearing loss resulting from rupture of the oval window is not limited to high-frequency sounds.

E) CORRECT:

NIHL is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells of the organ of Corti. In a normally functioning ear, sound waves are transmitted mechanically through the tympanic membrane, via the ossicles, and through the oval window to the perilymph-filled inner ear. The resulting vibrations are transmitted to the cochlear hair cells, from where neurologic impulses are transmitted via the vestibulocochlear nerve. Repeated exposure to sounds louder than 85 dB, like those this man experiences at work, can damage the hair cells of the organ of Corti and result in subsequent sensorineural hearing loss that typically affects high-frequency hearing first. Additionally, exposure to sudden, extremely loud noise greater than 120 dB can lead to the rupture of the tympanic membrane, which would cause conductive hearing loss.
Image Description:

Audiogram of a young adult

There is a bilateral reduction in air and bone conduction as 4000 Hz.

This finding is typical of noise-induced sensorineural hearing loss

F) INCORRECT:

Excess endolymphatic fluid pressure resulting in sensorineural hearing loss is seen in Meniere disease. Symptoms are usually unilateral and typically include hearing loss, aural fullness, episodic vertigo, and tinnitus, none of which are present in this patient. Additionally, the sensorineural hearing loss in Meniere disease usually affects lower-frequency sounds and is unilateral. The patient described in this case has high-frequency hearing loss that is bilateral, as suggested by the absence of lateralization on the Weber test.
questions.hint: Bilateral high-frequency hearing loss in a patient with occupational noise exposure should raise concern for noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL). The absence of lateralization on Weber tests suggests that both ears are equally affected, while the normal Rinne test suggests that the hearing loss is sensorineural in origin.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of hearing loss. To test her hearing, the physician performs two tests. First, a vibrating tuning fork is held against the mastoid bone of the patient and then near her ear, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on both sides when the tuning fork is held near her ear. Next, the physician holds the tuning fork against the bridge of her forehead, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on the right side than the left. The patient's examination findings are most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction is associated with conductive hearing loss due to direct obstruction of the external acoustic canal. If cerumen impaction were present on the right side, the patient would have a negative Rinne test on the right and a positive test on the left. The Weber test would lateralize to the right side.

B) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis is characterized by conductive hearing loss (more in the lower frequencies than in the higher), typically bilateral. It most commonly manifests in the third or fourth decade of life. If otosclerosis were present on the left side, the patient would have a negative Rinne test on the left and a positive test on the right. The Weber test would lateralize to the left.

C) INCORRECT:

Cochlear ischemia can lead to direct cochlear nerve damage and thus cause unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, as seen here. In a patient with right-sided cochlear ischemia, the Rinne test would be positive on both sides. However, the Weber test would lateralize to the left because of right-sided nerve damage.

D) CORRECT:

Acoustic neuromas, which commonly arise from the internal acoustic canal, often exert a mass effect on the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). The resulting unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, as seen in this patient, is the most common early symptom of this condition. Other symptoms include tinnitus due to pressure on CN VIII as well as dizziness/vertigo and gait instability due to vestibular deficits.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

E) INCORRECT:

Presbycusis is the most common cause of sensorineural hearing loss, with onset most commonly occurring in the sixth decade of life. It typically manifests with difficulty hearing in noisy environments. If bilateral presbycusis were present, the patient would have positive Rinne tests on the right and left. The Weber test would not lateralize.

F) INCORRECT:

Cholesteatoma does not always present with hearing loss, but would cause conductive hearing loss due to erosion of the ossicles. In a case of a symptomatic cholesteatoma on the right side, this patient would have a negative Rinne test on the right and a positive test on the left. The Weber test would lateralize to the right side.
questions.hint: In this patient, the results of the Rinne test are positive, indicating normal conductive hearing. In combination with a Weber test that lateralized to the right, this indicates left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the veterans’ administration outpatient clinic because of ringing in his ears and worsening difficulty hearing. He has had gradually increasing difficulties hearing conversations in crowded places, which he first noticed 3 years ago. He has also felt depressed, and he noticed that he regularly thinks back to his time in the military. The patient retired from the military 1 month ago when he returned from a deployment to Syria where he was involved in active combat. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows a clear translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the right mastoid process. Immediately after the patient stops hearing a tone, the tuning fork is held over the right ear and he reports hearing the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the left side and shows the same pattern. The vibrating tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient hears the sound in the center of his head. The results of an audiogram are shown. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's impaired hearing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ototoxic medications such as loop diuretics, aminoglycosides, vancomycin, or cisplatin can cause tinnitus and bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, which are present here. However, this patient's only current medication is hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, which is not known to be ototoxic.

B) INCORRECT:

Meniere disease, which is caused by endolymphatic hydrops, can lead to tinnitus and bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, both of which are seen here. However, in initial stages, the hearing loss in this condition would usually have a fluctuating course, be accompanied by a sensation of ear fullness, and primarily affect low frequencies. In addition, Meniere disease typically manifests with acute episodes of severe peripheral vertigo (a component of the Meniere triad). In contrast, this patient does not report vertigo or ear fullness and has progressive high-frequency hearing loss, while Meniere disease typically causes low to mid-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.
Image Description:

Audiograms of a patient with Meniere disease in the left ear

Left audiogram (at first presentation): normal hearing in both ears

Right audiogram (2 years later): sensorineural hearing loss to low and midfrequency signals in the left ear; normal hearing in the right ear

Asymmetric fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss is a characteristic feature of Meniere disease.

Circle: hearing threshold of the right ear; Square: hearing threshold of the left ear

C) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis, which leads to fixation of the stapes bone in the oval window, can affect both ears and cause progressive bilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, as seen here. However, the hearing loss in this condition is conductive rather than sensorineural; therefore, a negative rather than positive Rinne test would be expected. Moreover, patients with otosclerosis hear better in crowded environments (paracusis willisii) and have a characteristic notched hearing loss at 2 kHz (Carhart notch) on an audiogram unlike this patient who has difficulty hearing in crowded places and a notch at 3–4 kHz. Additionally, otoscopic examination in patients with active otosclerosis would usually reveal a red-blue hue seen through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign) as opposed to a clear, translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex.
Image Description:

Audiogram of a patient with otosclerosis in the right ear.

Air conduction is reduced in the affected ear by approx. 35dB. Bone conduction shows a characteristic notched hearing loss at 2000Hz (Carhart notch). These are characteristic findings of otosclerosis, a condition that causes conductive hearing loss due to the fixation of the stapes to the oval window.

D) INCORRECT:

Presbycusis is the most common type of sensorineural hearing loss. This condition leads to progressive bilateral hearing loss with impairment of high-frequency hearing and tinnitus, both of which are seen here. However, presbycusis is usually first noticed in the sixth decade of life and the audiogram shows hearing impairment across a wide spectrum of high frequencies rather than a pronounced notch at a specific frequency.
Image Description:

Frequency-dependent auditory threshold, measured via air and bone conduction: In presbycusis, patients struggle to hear the higher frequencies in both air and bone conduction.

E) INCORRECT:

Ear barotrauma can be caused by flying or explosions (blast injuries), both of which this patient has likely been exposed to, and can lead to bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. However, sensorineural hearing loss in this condition results from rupture of the oval window membrane and would be accompanied by nausea and vertigo. More commonly, barotrauma manifests with conductive hearing loss, which would show a different pattern on tuning fork tests and audiogram. In addition, symptom onset is sudden rather than progressive and affected patients typically present with a feeling of pressure and/or stabbing ear pain. Finally, otoscopic examination would reveal hematotympanum as opposed to a clear, translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex.

F) CORRECT:

Repeated exposure to sounds above a threshold of 85 dB (e.g., motorcycle) or a single exposure to sounds above 120 dB (e.g., gunshots, jet takeoffs) can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. Sensorineural hearing loss is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of the hair cells in the organ of Corti. Deployed military personnel, like this patient, have a high occupational risk of developing noise-induced hearing loss. Such hearing loss is slowly progressive and affects high frequencies (3–4 kHz) first, which results in difficulty hearing in crowded environments. Tinnitus is often an associated symptom. There is no definitive treatment available (besides hearing aids); therefore, prevention with appropriate hearing protection is essential. In addition to sensorineural hearing loss, exposure to sudden noise louder than 120 dB can cause conductive hearing loss through rupture of the tympanic membrane.

Hearing loss is a risk factor for depressive disorders, which are common among veterans.
questions.hint: A bilaterally positive Rinne test and absent lateralization of sound during the Weber test in a patient with difficulty hearing indicate bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His difficulty hearing conversations in crowded places is suggestive of high-frequency hearing loss, which is evident on the audiogram (notch between 3–4 kHz).

questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman, accompanied by her daughters, presents for evaluation of hearing loss. She reports that her overall health has been good but that during the past 6 months to one year, hearing over the telephone has become more difficult for her. She is unable to say which ear is worse. Her daughters state that she has become withdrawn from her social circle and does not go out much. She reports no dizziness, pain, or drainage from the ears. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has taken low-dose aspirin for the past 10 years.
On examination, the patient’s ear canals and tympanic membranes are normal. Her Weber test response is midline, and a Rinne test is positive (i.e., air conduction is better than bone conduction) bilaterally. An audiogram reveals symmetric, bilateral, moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss that is more pronounced at high frequencies.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most accurate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Meniere disease refers to the triad of fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, and tinnitus. Onset of symptoms is usually unilateral. The hearing loss is a low-frequency sensorineural loss.

B) CORRECT:

Presbycusis, or age-related hearing loss, is routinely underdiagnosed. In affected patients, an audiogram will reveal down-sloping sensorineural hearing loss that is more severe at high frequencies. The consequences of untreated presbycusis include social withdrawal, depression, and poor quality of life. Amplification with hearing aids can significantly improve speech perception, understanding, and hearing-related quality of life.

Key learning point: In an older patient, bilateral symmetric hearing loss that is more severe at high frequencies points to a diagnosis of presbycusis (age-related hearing loss).

C) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin has been reported to cause tinnitus but not hearing loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hearing loss can cause bilateral sensorineural hearing loss but is typically a rapidly progressive hearing loss that develops over weeks to a few months.

E) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis is a genetic disorder characterized by conductive hearing loss from fixation of the stapes bone. The Rinne test is negative, with bone conduction better than air conduction. The loss is greater in the low frequencies.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman reports a feeling of fullness in her left ear that began while she was cooking dinner the previous evening. She also noticed popping in the left ear and mild dizziness at the time, and she now reports a new inability to understand her son's voice through her cell phone on the left side. She has not had any ear pain, drainage, nasal congestion, or upper respiratory symptoms. She is otherwise healthy and has no otologic history.
Inspection of the ears, nose, and throat reveals no abnormal findings, and an otoscopic examination is normal. The patient is unable to hear a finger rub on the left side. On tuning-fork examination, the Weber test lateralizes to the right side, and the Rinne test is positive (i.e., air conduction is better than bone conduction) bilaterally.
Which one of the following initial management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Follow-up examination in 2 weeks if symptoms persist
Oxymetazoline nasal spray and oral pseudoephedrine

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Idiopathic sudden sensorineural hearing loss is a form of hearing loss that manifests as popping or crackling in the ear, followed by a whooshing/ringing tinnitus and aural fullness. Mild vestibular symptoms are present in up to half of affected patients. The incidence of sudden hearing loss is about 1 in 10,000.

Otoscopic examination is usually unremarkable. Comparing the hearing between the two ears using a finger rub or phone dial tone supports the loss of hearing. The Weber tuning-fork test will help confirm whether the loss is conductive or sensorineural. The sound should lateralize to the side of a conductive hearing loss or the side opposite of a sensorineural hearing loss.

Sudden hearing loss is an otologic emergency. Early treatment with a 2-week course of high-dose oral prednisone is associated with improved outcomes only if initiated within the first 7 to 10 days. In addition, the patient should undergo an audiogram and MRI with contrast to rule out demyelinating disease, neoplasm, or stroke.

Treatment with intratympanic glucocorticoid injections has been associated with the same odds of hearing recovery as oral glucocorticoids, making it an excellent alternative for patients with diabetes mellitus and those with a contraindication to high-dose oral glucocorticoids. Some clinicians have tried providing both oral and intratympanic glucocorticoids instead of one or the other, but the results are the same no matter which option is chosen. Nasal decongestants and antibiotics have no appropriate role in treating this condition. The patient should undergo an audiogram and MRI with contrast to rule out demyelinating disease, neoplasm, or stroke.

Key learning point: Idiopathic sudden sensorineural hearing loss should be treated promptly with high-dose oral prednisone.

B) INCORRECT:

Sudden hearing loss is an otologic emergency. Early treatment with a 2-week course of high-dose oral prednisone is associated with improved outcomes only if initiated within the first 7 to 10 days.

C) INCORRECT:

Nasal decongestants and antibiotics have no appropriate role in treating this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Nasal decongestants and antibiotics have no appropriate role in treating this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Nasal decongestants and antibiotics have no appropriate role in treating this condition.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is evaluated for behavioral difficulties. She is enrolled in preschool but has been having trouble following instructions in the classroom. At home, she does not come when called, and she ignores her mother’s requests. It is difficult for strangers to understand most of what she says. She gets frustrated easily and has temper tantrums.
She was born full term with no complications in the newborn period. Her newborn hearing screen was normal. She has had four episodes of otitis media during the past 6 months; they have been treated with oral antibiotics.
Tympanometry screening in the office shows bilateral flat lines. On audiometry, bone conduction is better than air conduction bilaterally.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A perilymph fistula causes sensorineural hearing loss, as well as intermittent hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus, and ear fullness. This diagnosis is inconsistent with this child's findings, which suggest conductive rather than sensorineural hearing loss.

B) CORRECT:

This child has a history of recurrent otitis media, abnormal tympanogram results bilaterally, and an audiogram pattern showing bone conduction to be better than air conduction. This clinical picture is most consistent with a conductive hearing loss caused by a middle-ear effusion. In a preschool-age child, this may manifest as inattention or behavior problems and, if untreated, can lead to cognitive or speech and language problems.

Key learning point: A 4-year-old child with concerns of inattention and a history of recurrent otitis media should be evaluated for hearing impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

Aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin, are toxic to cochlear hair cells and can lead to sensorineural hearing loss. With a history consisting only of ear infections, this child is unlikely to have been exposed to aminoglycosides. Furthermore, her clinical findings suggest conductive rather than sensorineural hearing loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital cytomegalovirus infection causes progressive sensorineural hearing loss. This diagnosis is inconsistent with this child's findings, which suggest conductive rather than sensorineural hearing loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Cholesteatoma is a less common complication of recurrent otitis media than middle-ear effusion. Children with cholesteatoma present with unilateral conductive hearing loss, chronic ear drainage, and an abnormal otoscopic examination (with a pearly white mass observed behind the tympanic membrane, a retraction pocket, or an area of granulation tissue at the periphery of the membrane). Prior placement of tympanostomy tubes increases risk.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of progressive hearing loss in both ears over the past year. He has difficulties understanding conversations in crowded places and when more than one person talks at the same time. Otoscopic examination shows pearly gray, translucent tympanic membranes with a normal light reflex. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Once the patient no longer hears a tone, the fork is held over the ipsilateral ear and the patient reports hearing the tone again. The same test is repeated on the right side with similar results. There is no lateralization when a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction is a buildup of tightly packed cerumen in the outer ear. It often manifests with unilateral conductive hearing loss and earache, and is easily diagnosed by direct visualization by otoscopic examination. This patient has bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and clear tympanic membranes on examination.
Image Description:

Otoscopic image of the external auditory canal

The auditory canal is completely obscured by a yellow-brown lump of cerumen.

B) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis predominantly affects women aged 20–40 years and leads to conductive hearing loss, usually ultimately bilateral, which presents with a negative Rinne test as opposed to the sensorineural hearing loss seen in this patient. Additionally, patients also develop tinnitus and usually hear better in noisy rather than quiet surroundings.

C) INCORRECT:

Cholesteatoma manifests with conductive hearing loss, which would lead to a negative Rinne test, and if unilateral, lateralization to the affected ear on Weber test. In addition, it typically leads to painless otorrhea and a brownish, irregular mass on otoscopy, none of which is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Although a vestibulocochlear nerve lesion presents with sensorineural hearing loss, it also leads to vestibular symptoms such as vertigo or horizontal nystagmus, none of which are present in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Presbycusis is a form of sensorineural hearing loss that affects more than half of adults by the age of 75 years, most adults over 80 years of age, and nearly all adults ≥ 90 years of age. It is a multifactorial process caused by gradual degeneration of the organ of Corti over the course of years, often first identified by difficulty hearing in crowded spaces. Although there is no definitive treatment, hearing aids and cochlear implants can provide symptomatic relief and improve hearing function in affected individuals.
questions.hint: This older patient presents with progressive bilateral hearing loss and difficulty hearing in noisy, crowded environments. These features together with bilateral positive Rinne test and no lateralization on Weber test are suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of hearing loss. He reports difficulty hearing sounds like the beeping of the microwave or birds chirping, but can easily hear the pipe organ at church. He works as an aircraft marshaller. A Rinne test shows air conduction greater than bone conduction bilaterally. A Weber test does not lateralize. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Damage to the organ of Corti

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Perforation of the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss and thus results in an abnormal Rinne test. Tympanic membrane perforation can be caused by foreign body trauma, temporal bone fractures, otitis media, barotrauma, or blast injury. While this patient's occupation puts him at increased risk of damage to the ear, there is nothing in this patient's history to suggest tympanic membrane perforation and the Rinne test was normal, indicating that he does not have conductive hearing loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Immobility of the stapes is the cause of otosclerosis, which can result in conductive hearing loss. The stapes lies against the oval window and transmits sounds from the tympanic membrane. In otosclerosis, the ossicles are rendered immobile by extensive bony remodeling. Patients usually present with bilateral conductive hearing loss and have an abnormal Rinne test. Otosclerosis would not be responsible for the bilateral sensorineural hearing loss seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

External compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve can be caused by tumors such as acoustic neuromas, which are usually unilateral, although they may be bilateral in neurofibromatosis type 2. Compression of this nerve would also result in sensorineural hearing loss. However, acoustic neuromas are usually accompanied by dizziness and ataxia, and they are unlikely to cause isolated symmetrical high-frequency hearing loss. Given this patient's history of chronic exposure to loud noises, a different etiology of his hearing loss is much more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the oval window is a cause of hearing loss associated with barotrauma. Sudden decreases in pressure between the inner and outer ear cause dissolved gasses to be released from the perilymphatic fluid in the inner ear and results in rupture of the oval window. Patients with barotrauma will have a recent history of diving or flying, which this patient does not. In addition, the sensorineural hearing loss resulting from rupture of the oval window is not limited to high-frequency sounds.

E) CORRECT:

NIHL is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells of the organ of Corti. In a normally functioning ear, sound waves are transmitted mechanically through the tympanic membrane, via the ossicles, and through the oval window to the perilymph-filled inner ear. The resulting vibrations are transmitted to the cochlear hair cells, from where neurologic impulses are transmitted via the vestibulocochlear nerve. Repeated exposure to sounds louder than 85 dB, like those this man experiences at work, can damage the hair cells of the organ of Corti and result in subsequent sensorineural hearing loss that typically affects high-frequency hearing first. Additionally, exposure to sudden, extremely loud noise greater than 120 dB can lead to the rupture of the tympanic membrane, which would cause conductive hearing loss.
Image Description:

Audiogram of a young adult

There is a bilateral reduction in air and bone conduction as 4000 Hz.

This finding is typical of noise-induced sensorineural hearing loss
questions.hint: Bilateral high-frequency hearing loss in a patient with occupational noise exposure should raise concern for noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL). The absence of lateralization on Weber tests suggests that both ears are equally affected, while the normal Rinne test suggests that the hearing loss is sensorineural in origin.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 62-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-year history of hearing loss. To test her hearing, two tests are performed. First, a vibrating tuning fork is held against the mastoid bone of the patient and then near her ear, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on both sides when the tuning fork is held near her ear. Next, the tuning fork is held against the bridge of her forehead, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on the right side than the left. The patient's examination findings are most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction is associated with conductive hearing loss due to direct obstruction of the external acoustic canal. If cerumen impaction were present on the right side, the patient would have a negative Rinne test on the right and a positive test on the left. The Weber test would lateralize to the right side.

B) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis is characterized by conductive hearing loss (more in the lower frequencies than in the higher), typically bilateral. It most commonly manifests in the third or fourth decade of life. If otosclerosis were present on the left side, the patient would have a negative Rinne test on the left and a positive test on the right. The Weber test would lateralize to the left.

C) INCORRECT:

Cochlear ischemia can lead to direct cochlear nerve damage and thus cause unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, as seen here. In a patient with right-sided cochlear ischemia, the Rinne test would be positive on both sides. However, the Weber test would lateralize to the left because of right-sided nerve damage.

D) CORRECT:

Acoustic neuromas, which commonly arise from the internal acoustic canal, often exert a mass effect on the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). The resulting unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, as seen in this patient, is the most common early symptom of this condition. Other symptoms include tinnitus due to pressure on CN VIII as well as dizziness/vertigo and gait instability due to vestibular deficits.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

E) INCORRECT:

Presbycusis is the most common cause of sensorineural hearing loss, with onset most commonly occurring in the sixth decade of life. It typically manifests with difficulty hearing in noisy environments. If bilateral presbycusis were present, the patient would have positive Rinne tests on the right and left. The Weber test would not lateralize.
questions.hint: In this patient, the results of the Rinne test are positive, indicating normal conductive hearing. In combination with a Weber test that lateralized to the right, this indicates left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents for evaluation of hearing loss. During the past 6 months to one year, hearing over the telephone has become more difficult for her. She has become withdrawn from her social circle and does not go out much. She has taken low-dose aspirin for the past 10 years. On examination, Weber test response is midline and Rinne test is positive bilaterally. An audiogram reveals symmetric, bilateral, moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss that is more pronounced at high frequencies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Meniere disease refers to the triad of fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, and tinnitus. Onset of symptoms is usually unilateral. The hearing loss is a low-frequency sensorineural loss.

B) CORRECT:

Presbycusis, or age-related hearing loss, is routinely underdiagnosed. In affected patients, an audiogram will reveal down-sloping sensorineural hearing loss that is more severe at high frequencies. The consequences of untreated presbycusis include social withdrawal, depression, and poor quality of life. Amplification with hearing aids can significantly improve speech perception, understanding, and hearing-related quality of life.

Key learning point: In an older patient, bilateral symmetric hearing loss that is more severe at high frequencies points to a diagnosis of presbycusis (age-related hearing loss).

C) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin has been reported to cause tinnitus but not hearing loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hearing loss can cause bilateral sensorineural hearing loss but is typically a rapidly progressive hearing loss that develops over weeks to a few months.

E) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis is a genetic disorder characterized by conductive hearing loss from fixation of the stapes bone. The Rinne test is negative, with bone conduction better than air conduction. The loss is greater in the low frequencies.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman has progressive memory loss and frequently asks people to repeat themselves. Neurologic and lab evaluations are unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Donepezil, a cholinesterase inhibitor, is used for Alzheimer disease to improve cognitive symptoms. However, without a confirmed diagnosis of Alzheimer disease, initiating donepezil is premature. The patient has unremarkable neurologic and lab evaluations, indicating the need for further cognitive assessment before starting treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Depression screening is relevant when cognitive complaints may be due to depression, especially pseudodementia. However, this patient presents with memory loss and difficulty understanding conversation, without signs of depression. The focus should be on cognitive decline rather than mood disorders.

C) CORRECT:

In elderly patients with progressive memory loss and frequent requests for repetition, hearing impairment should be considered. Formal audiometry assesses hearing function and can identify sensorineural hearing loss, which is common in older adults. Identifying hearing loss is crucial, as it can mimic or exacerbate cognitive decline, ensuring that communication deficits are not misinterpreted as primary cognitive issues.

Key learning point: In elderly patients with cognitive deficits, evaluating for hearing loss is important as it can significantly impact cognitive function and communication.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI is used to assess structural brain abnormalities in cognitive decline. However, in a patient with normal neurologic and lab evaluations, frequent requests for repetition suggest hearing impairment rather than a central neurologic process. MRI is more appropriate when focal neurologic deficits or atypical features are present.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of hearing loss. He reports difficulty hearing high-pitched sounds such as the beeping of the microwave or birds chirping, but can easily hear lower-pitched sounds like the pipe organ at church. He works as an aircraft marshaller. On examination, a Rinne test shows air conduction greater than bone conduction bilaterally, and a Weber test does not lateralize. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?

choices.text: Damage to the organ of Corti.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

NIHL is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells of the organ of Corti. In a normally functioning ear, sound waves are transmitted mechanically through the tympanic membrane, via the ossicles, and through the oval window to the perilymph-filled inner ear. The resulting vibrations are transmitted to the cochlear hair cells, from where neurologic impulses are transmitted via the vestibulocochlear nerve. Repeated exposure to sounds louder than 85 dB, like those this man experiences at work, can damage the hair cells of the organ of Corti and result in subsequent sensorineural hearing loss that typically affects high-frequency hearing first. Additionally, exposure to sudden, extremely loud noise greater than 120 dB can lead to the rupture of the tympanic membrane, which would cause conductive hearing loss.

Key learning point: Noise-induced hearing loss is caused by irreversible damage to the hair cells of the organ of Corti, typically resulting in high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.
Image Description:

Audiogram of a young adult

There is a bilateral reduction in air and bone conduction as 4000 Hz.

This finding is typical of noise-induced sensorineural hearing loss

B) INCORRECT:

Perforation of the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss and thus results in an abnormal Rinne test. Tympanic membrane perforation can be caused by foreign body trauma, temporal bone fractures, otitis media, barotrauma, or blast injury. While this patient's occupation puts him at increased risk of damage to the ear, there is nothing in this patient's history to suggest tympanic membrane perforation and the Rinne test was normal, indicating that he does not have conductive hearing loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Immobility of the stapes is the cause of otosclerosis, which can result in conductive hearing loss. The stapes lies against the oval window and transmits sounds from the tympanic membrane. In otosclerosis, the ossicles are rendered immobile by extensive bony remodeling. Patients usually present with bilateral conductive hearing loss and have an abnormal Rinne test. Otosclerosis would not be responsible for the bilateral sensorineural hearing loss seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

External compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve can be caused by tumors such as acoustic neuromas, which are usually unilateral, although they may be bilateral in neurofibromatosis type 2. Compression of this nerve would also result in sensorineural hearing loss. However, acoustic neuromas are usually accompanied by dizziness and ataxia, and they are unlikely to cause isolated symmetrical high-frequency hearing loss. Given this patient's history of chronic exposure to loud noises, a different etiology of his hearing loss is much more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the oval window is a cause of hearing loss associated with barotrauma. Sudden decreases in pressure between the inner and outer ear cause dissolved gasses to be released from the perilymphatic fluid in the inner ear and results in rupture of the oval window. Patients with barotrauma will have a recent history of diving or flying, which this patient does not. In addition, the sensorineural hearing loss resulting from rupture of the oval window is not limited to high-frequency sounds.
questions.hint: Bilateral high-frequency hearing loss in a patient with occupational noise exposure should raise concern for noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL). The absence of lateralization on Weber tests suggests that both ears are equally affected, while the normal Rinne test suggests that the hearing loss is sensorineural in origin.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-year history of hearing loss. She is otherwise healthy. You perform two hearing tests. First, you place a vibrating tuning fork against her mastoid bone and then near her ear; she reports hearing the sound better on both sides when the tuning fork is near her ear. Next, you place the tuning fork on the bridge of her forehead; she reports hearing the sound better on the right side than the left. Which one of the following conditions is most consistent with these examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cochlear ischemia can lead to direct cochlear nerve damage and thus cause unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, as seen here. In a patient with right-sided cochlear ischemia, the Rinne test would be positive on both sides. However, the Weber test would lateralize to the left because of right-sided nerve damage.

B) CORRECT:

Acoustic neuromas, which commonly arise from the internal acoustic canal, often exert a mass effect on the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). The resulting unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, as seen in this patient, is the most common early symptom of this condition. Other symptoms include tinnitus due to pressure on CN VIII as well as dizziness/vertigo and gait instability due to vestibular deficits.

Key learning point: Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with Weber test lateralizing to the unaffected ear suggests an acoustic neuroma affecting the ipsilateral vestibulocochlear nerve.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

C) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis is characterized by conductive hearing loss (more in the lower frequencies than in the higher), typically bilateral. It most commonly manifests in the third or fourth decade of life. If otosclerosis were present on the left side, the patient would have a negative Rinne test on the left and a positive test on the right. The Weber test would lateralize to the left.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerumen impaction is associated with conductive hearing loss due to direct obstruction of the external acoustic canal. If cerumen impaction were present on the right side, the patient would have a negative Rinne test on the right and a positive test on the left. The Weber test would lateralize to the right side.

E) INCORRECT:

Presbycusis is the most common cause of sensorineural hearing loss, with onset most commonly occurring in the sixth decade of life. It typically manifests with difficulty hearing in noisy environments. If bilateral presbycusis were present, the patient would have positive Rinne tests on the right and left. The Weber test would not lateralize.
questions.hint: In this patient, the results of the Rinne test are positive, indicating normal conductive hearing. In combination with a Weber test that lateralized to the right, this indicates left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman comes to your clinic for evaluation of hearing loss. Over the past 6 to 12 months, she has found it increasingly difficult to hear over the telephone. She reports becoming more socially withdrawn and rarely goes out. She has been taking low-dose aspirin for the past 10 years. On examination, the Weber test is midline and the Rinne test is positive bilaterally. Audiogram shows symmetric, bilateral, moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss, more pronounced at high frequencies. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hearing loss can cause bilateral sensorineural hearing loss but is typically a rapidly progressive hearing loss that develops over weeks to a few months.

B) CORRECT:

Presbycusis, or age-related hearing loss, is routinely underdiagnosed. In affected patients, an audiogram will reveal down-sloping sensorineural hearing loss that is more severe at high frequencies. The consequences of untreated presbycusis include social withdrawal, depression, and poor quality of life. Amplification with hearing aids can significantly improve speech perception, understanding, and hearing-related quality of life.

Key learning point: In an older patient, bilateral symmetric hearing loss that is more severe at high frequencies points to a diagnosis of presbycusis (age-related hearing loss).

C) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis is a genetic disorder characterized by conductive hearing loss from fixation of the stapes bone. The Rinne test is negative, with bone conduction better than air conduction. The loss is greater in the low frequencies.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin has been reported to cause tinnitus but not hearing loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Meniere disease refers to the triad of fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, and tinnitus. Onset of symptoms is usually unilateral. The hearing loss is a low-frequency sensorineural loss.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 2-year-old with minimal word use is brought for evaluation. Which test is most appropriate initially?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the head is considered when structural brain abnormalities are suspected, such as in cases with seizures or neurological deficits. This child is otherwise healthy with isolated speech delay, lacking neurological signs or trauma history. Evaluating common causes like hearing impairment is prioritized over neuroimaging, which is invasive and costly.

B) CORRECT:

In children with speech delay, assessing hearing is crucial, as even minor hearing deficits can impair language development. Audiological evaluation, including otoacoustic emissions and auditory brainstem responses, determines the integrity of the auditory system. Early detection of hearing impairment allows for timely intervention, which can prevent further language delays. This evaluation is a fundamental step before considering other specialized assessments or interventions.

Key learning point: In children with delayed speech and language development, a hearing test is the most appropriate initial test to rule out hearing impairment as a potential cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Chromosomal microarray is used for global developmental delays or congenital anomalies, often with dysmorphic features. This child, with isolated speech delay and no additional concerns, does not warrant genetic evaluation. Initial assessments focus on hearing impairment or speech disorders.

D) INCORRECT:

Before referring a child for speech therapy, it is essential to rule out organic causes of speech delay, such as hearing impairment. Audiologic assessment ensures auditory function is intact. Speech therapy is important for confirmed speech delays but should follow the exclusion of hearing issues.
